title: Why do so many news articles have misleading headlines? - Quora

response.answer_text: News Articles — (real news articles) typically do not. Occasionally, it happens, but that is somewhat rare, and it should not occur. It may happen is a smaller venue, where a legitimate journalist has written a solid article, but the ownership is also the editor, and the the owner wishes to introduce his or her own partisan “spin.” I suspect, though - what you are referring to is a much larger problem. Some call it “clickbait.” These are instances where the article in not even news, at all. One propagandist has written a story (which may be made up, or fictional, or exaggeration, or an editorial of some sorts). Then, the person who hired them tries to construct an even more outrageously fictional headline — to entice people to click and read the underlying story (hoping they will believe the headline, regardless of that the article actually states.) That is a pervasive problem. Note, though — that is not news. That is not a “news article.” That is an attempt to spread misinformation, and disinformation, and propaganda. Sometimes, it is a resource set up deliberately to help someone’s political campaign. Sometimes, it is a resource set up deliberately to entice you to visit a website, to increase profits (from advertising, or from “paid for clicks” schemes). Learn the difference between legitimate journalism and editorial content, and advertising — and you are usually able to avoid such nonsense. Hope this helps.

The simple answer is because headlines are crafted to get as much attention as possible. Most mainstream outlets have limits as to how far to push the line. Clearly deceptive headlines eventually turn people off. The longer answer includes other reasons, including whether you’re looking at an article published by a responsible news organization. In most mainstream newsrooms, a different person usually writes the headlines and some “deceptive” headlines may be unintentional. It’s possible the headline writer doesn’t understand the story as well as the reporter, or it’s difficult to fully capture a complex topic in a simple sentence. Also, headlines used to be written by senior-level editors with years of experience. Nowadays, it’s more likely to be a much less experienced, overworked, (and low paid) staffer.
